Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Beyond Thermal Separations: Development of Ultra High Pressure Reverse Osmosis Membranes for Energy Efficient Desalination of Hypersaline Brines

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI Name: Menachem Elimelech
Proposal Number: CBET 1701658

The treatment of high-salinity industrial wastewaters, such as those from the oil and gas industry, coal-fired power plants, and inland desalination facilities, is a major challenge. Rising costs and environmental concerns associated with the disposal of industrial wastewaters necessitate the development of low-cost, energy-efficient treatment technologies that can allow for water reuse while minimizing the volume of wastewater requiring disposal. Current thermal desalination technologies are relatively inefficient and expensive compared with membrane-based reverse osmosis (RO) processes, which have dramatically lowered the energy consumption and cost of seawater desalination; however, conventional RO can only treat or concentrate feedwaters up to approximately twice the salinity of seawater because of the limited maximum hydraulic pressure that current RO membrane systems can tolerate (typically about 75 bar). Therefore, conventional RO cannot be used to treat industrial wastewaters, which are typically several times more saline than seawater. The PIs seek to develop and characterize new RO membranes that can operate at very high pressures of up to 400 bar. These membranes will facilitate the development of high-pressure RO (HPRO) or ultra-high pressure RO (UHPRO) systems that are capable of treating high-salinity industrial wastewaters in an energy efficient and cost effective manner. To promote diversity and to enhance the involvement of under-represented groups in science and engineering, the PI will be engaged in Yale's K-12 outreach activities and in the training of undergraduate students through research and senior-level projects, and graduate student training for research and academic careers.

Specific objectives of the project include: (i) providing fundamental understanding of membrane compaction and the ideal support layer properties for highly pressure-tolerant TFC RO membranes, (ii) developing a polyamide selective layer using sacrificial nanostrand layers on polymeric and metallic supports tailored for HPRO and UHPRO operation, and (iii) analyzing water and salt transport behavior through RO membranes at ultra-high pressures and salinities. The PIs will develop new fabrication techniques for HPRO and UHPRO membranes and investigate fundamental membrane properties and mass transport behavior at ultra-high pressures and salinities. Such breakthrough membranes would enable the expanded application of RO to desalination/concentration of large volumes of highly saline brines, which would in turn result in significant energy and cost savings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The rising prevalence of water stress requires the utilization of untapped water sources to keep pace with freshwater demands in an increasingly populated and industrialized world. Desalination of hypersaline brines represents a promising opportunity to increase water availability, but it is currently expensive and energy intensive. Reverse osmosis (RO) is the primary desalination technology for seawater and brackish water, although material and process limitations preclude its use for hypersaline brines. The objective of this project is to advance high-pressure reverse osmosis (HPRO) for energy-efficient desalination of hypersaline brines. In doing so, this work aims to leverage the inherent energy efficiency of membrane-based processes to enable the widespread desalination of high-salinity brines and increase global freshwater availability.

The high osmotic pressures of hypersaline brines require the application of hydraulic pressures exceeding the capabilities of conventional RO membranes and processes. Therefore, inefficient, expensive thermal desalination technologies must be used for brine desalination. This research has modeled the expected energy consumption of HPRO and demonstrated that it requires 2–3 times less energy than thermal desalination. Nevertheless, several material and process design challenges must be addressed for the development of HPRO. These include the need to synthesize compaction-resistant membranes, understand transport in high-salinity environments, and design modules for high-pressure applications. These aspects, and others, are discussed at-length in this work to provide a roadmap for the academic and industrial development of HPRO.

A critical need for the development of HPRO is to understand the impact of compaction to decrease water permeability in pressure-driven membrane processes. The study of HPRO, however, requires the ability to evaluate membrane performance at unconventional pressures and salinities. Therefore, this project reports on the design and construction of an HPRO apparatus capable of testing membranes at hydraulic pressures up to 150 bar. As a result, the fundamental nature of compaction in thin film composite (TFC) membranes is evaluated. Support layers are identified to be primarily susceptible to compaction while positron annihilation lifetime spectroscopy demonstrates that selective layers do not compact irreversibly. Novel mechanisms are also proposed, and validated through experiments, to describe the role of hydraulic pressure to cause TFC membrane compaction. Specifically, a difference in hydraulic pressure across the support–selective layer interface generates a compaction force exerted on the support layer, causing deformation until an equivalent reaction force is generated. This deformation causes support layer surface porosity to decrease substantially, which is identified to cause compaction-related water permeability declines.

The design of compaction-resistant membranes for HPRO is dependent on the development of novel, mechanically robust support layers. Semi-crystalline polymers are promising materials for the design of membranes with improved mechanical properties owing to their favorable strength and processability. As such, a novel membrane synthesis method—extruded nonsolvent induced phase separation (eNIPS)—is developed to enable the fabrication of semi-crystalline support layers that are expected to improve membrane mechanical properties and compaction resistance. X-ray diffraction confirms that eNIPS and careful control of synthesis parameters increases polymer crystallinity and chain alignment by 5–15%. Mechanical properties are also evaluated in this work, which underscore the need for a greater fundamental understanding of the relationship between membrane morphology and mechanical properties.

The project has proposed the opportunity for HPRO to enable the energy-efficient desalination of hypersaline brines, while also addressing the most critical research needs for its development. In doing so, novel materials and processes have been developed, mechanisms have been proposed, and unconventional equipment has been designed. This multi-faceted study of HPRO has combined fundamental science with industrially relevant process design considerations to contribute to the displacement of energy-intensive thermal desalination technologies. As a result, it has guided the study of pressure-driven membrane processes into the high-salinity regime and laid a strong foundation for the energy-efficient desalination of hypersaline brines via HPRO.

The project was also used to train undergraduate and graduate students as well as several postdoctoral researchers. These individuals are carrying these skills forward in their current professional and academic careers.
